title: McDonald’s tell customer she can’t pay with a Scottish bank note
text:
Karen Wilson with her mum Margaret (Picture: MEN Media)

A woman was refused at a McDonald’s counter because she tried to pay with a Scottish £10 note.

Karen Wilson, 45, wanted to get a burger and fries while visiting the fast food chain with her mum.

But they weren’t able to use the bank note, when a machine did not recognise it.

Karen, from Edinburgh, walked out of the branch in Hull’s Jameson Street in disgust and went to KFC instead.

She told Hull Live: ‘The man had some sort of machine and he was fiddling around under the counter for a while and said the machine wasn’t accepting the note.

‘So we asked for the manager and he went to get her, and she said this machine that checks currency wasn’t taking the Scottish note.

She tried to pay with a Scottish £10 note (Picture: Getty)

‘It was quite frustrating, you don’t expect it at a huge chain like McDonald’s, maybe at a little local shop but not there.’

She said she and her mum visit Hull a few times a year to see friends and for her mum, who is from the city, to lay flowers for her parents at the cemetery.

Scottish banknotes are legally currency and are widely accepted in England, as well as north of the border.

When you go to pay £9 for 2 donuts (yes, really) in London and your £10 Bank of Scotland note is refused because “we only take British ones”. 🤔🤣 pic.twitter.com/SCCzIfolDn — judy murray (@JudyMurray) April 8, 2019

However, some run into problems trying to pay with them when they are not recognised.

Tennis player Andy Murray’s mother Judy Murrary had trouble earlier this year when she tried to pay for doughnuts with a Scottish £10 note.

Karen said she complained to McDonalds, who told her each store accepts currency from outside England and Wales ‘at their discretion’.
